news.title: 300,000-Year-Old Hearth Found In Qesem Cave; Ancient ‘Campfire’ Sheds Light On Human Culture [PHOTOS]
news.summary: Scientists have uncovered the remains of a 300,000-year-old hearth at the Qesem Cave, an archeological site seven miles east of Tel Aviv. Weizmann Institute

news.title: 300,000-Year-Old Hearth Discovered In Qesem Cave, Addresses Speculations On First Controlled Use of Fire
news.summary: A 300,000-Year-Old hearth has been discovered In Qesem Cave, shedding light on when humans began using fire for cooking and to build fire camps, Tel Aviv University researchers report.

news.title: Ancient Hearth Found In Israel Dates Back 300,000 Years, Scientists Say
news.summary: A newly discovered hearth full of ash and charred bone in a cave in modern-day Israel hints that early humans sat around fires as early as 300,000 years ago — before Homo sapiens arose in Africa. In and around the hearth, archaeologists say they also found

news.title: 300,000-year-old caveman 'campfire' found in Israel
news.summary: In and around the hearth, archaeologists say they also found bits of stone tools that were likely used for butchering and cutting animals

news.title: Scientists find signs of intelligent tool use 300,000 year old Qesem Cave
news.summary: © Zupancich, A. et al. / Scientific Reports Sixteen years ago, road workers detonated a controlled explosive to remove a large limestone boulder blocking a planned roadway outside of Tel Aviv in Israel.

wikipedia.title: Qesem Cave
wikipedia.summary: The Qesem Cave is an archeological site 12 km east of Tel Aviv in Israel that is dated during the Lower Paleolithic as having been occupied by early humans from before 382,000 to around 200,000 years ago.

wikipedia.title: Avi Gopher
wikipedia.summary: Avi Gopher is an Israeli archaeologist. He is a professor at the University of Tel Aviv.
